awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Software-defied HDDs: A System-centric Design Framework to Minimize Data Storage Cost for Data Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to develop storage system design techniques that can reduce the cost of hard disk drives (HDDs) for data centers. Based upon the observation that one could reduce the HDD cost by relaxing its storage reliability, the project will develop approaches that can accommodate low-cost but very unreliable HDDs in data centers without sacrificing the overall performance.

The project will cohesively exploit the unique characteristics of data centers and HDDs to develop cross-layer design techniques that can most effectively embrace very unreliable HDDs in data centers. In particular, the project will develop cross-layer design techniques to achieve: (a) hybrid local/distributed sector repair, (b) iterative cross-layer decoding-based sector repair, and (c) configurable per-sector protection. The project will further investigate the integration of these design techniques and explore the involved design trade-offs. A data center HDD simulator will be implemented to support the evaluations and design space exploration, and will be made publicly available to the research community.

The project could have significant impact on improving the cost effectiveness of mass data storage in data centers. The success of the project could lead to establishing a larger-scale inter-disciplinary research area covering data center storage systems, file system, coding theory, HDD firmware and read channel, and HDD manufacturing. The research training to both undergraduate and graduate students will address the concerns of lacking researchers and engineers with multi-disciplinary experience in computer industries. 

The main results will be research papers and a data center HDD simulator. The simulator source code and the corresponding documentation will be maintained on GitHub, where anyone can obtain and examine the most recent versions. Research papers will be available on the project web site at https://www.ecse.rpi.edu/homepages/tzhang/research.html. All the results will be kept publicly available for at least five years beyond the completion of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop solutions that can reduce the cost of magnetic recording hard disk drives (HDDs) for data centers. As the global digital data volume keeps exploding with an annual growth rate of over 60%, reliable and ever more affordable mass data storage HDDs are indispensable in the digital universe. It is important to study how future information technology infrastructure could most cost-effectively deploy large-capacity HDDs. 

This project has developed techniques that can accommodate very unreliable HDDs at minimal redundancy overhead and speed performance penalty. The key is to exploit the characteristics of data centers and HDDs cohesively and jointly. Without demanding significant changes to the existing software infrastructure, the developed design techniques enable future computing systems conveniently benefit from highly scaled magnetic recording technology. Design solutions have been comprehensively evaluated, and the research results have been published in technical papers in prestigious conferences.

The research accomplishments have significantly contributed to both academic and industry by developing innovative design solutions to effectively utilize large-capacity, low-cost HDDs in data centers. The adoption of the design solutions by the computing and storage industry will provide a direct benefit to this strategically important high technology sector critical to the economic health of the nation.
